I. 

INTRODUCTION 

1. 
The 13 Pacific developing member countries (PDMCs) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  have  a  total  population  of  about  8  million  people.  They  comprise  thousands  of  small 
islands scattered over an area almost as great as the land area of all ADB’s other developing 
member countries (DMCs) combined. The PDMCs constitute almost one third of ADB’s DMCs.  
 
2. 
These basic facts directly shape both the content and the delivery of ADB’s operational 
services  in  the  Pacific  region.  While  ADB’s  new  lending  commitments  have  averaged  about 
$100  million  per  year  recently,1  our  analytical  and  policy-related  work  are  an  especially 
important  operational  instrument.    Indeed,  the  ratio  of  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  lending 
volume in the PDMCs is seven times higher than the ADB average (Appendix 1).  This presents 
unique  demands,  but  also  unique  opportunities,  with  respect  to  program  formulation,  design, 
and supervision. 
  
3. 
In  September  2000,  ADB’s  Board  of  Directors  approved  an  ambitious  new  strategy 
designed  to  better  focus  ADB’s  analytical  and  operational  work  on  the  core  development 
challenges in the Pacific region. The Pacific Strategy for the New Millennium2 emphasized the 
need  for  deeper  ADB  engagement  in  several  critical  areas—through  our  operational  work;  by 
building  stronger  partnerships  across  the  community  of  development  partners;  and  by  tapping 
more  effectively  into  the  insights  and  resources  of  a  wider  range  of  partners,  including  the 
private sector.   
 
4. 
ADB has also taken a number of important steps over the past year to better organize 
and  align  its  operations  with  the  evolving  needs  of  the  PDMCs  and  with  these  strategic 
commitments.    In  January  2002,  the  Office  of  Pacific  Operations  was  upgraded  to  full 
department  status  while  maintaining  its  basic  structure  along  preexisting  lines.    With  a  full 
integration of “program” and “project” functions, Pacific Department (PARD) staff generally work 
in a matrix fashion, with flexibility in country assignments, and combining skills in programming, 
processing, and administration.  
 
5.  
As  an  extension  of  these  efforts,  ADB  has  done  a  comprehensive  analysis  of  options 
with respect to the physical location of PARD staff and, specifically, the merits of additional ADB 
offices  in  the  Pacific  region  (see  Appendix  1).    The  core  objective  in  this  work  has  been  to 
identify whether and how an expanded field presence could significantly strengthen our capacity 
to  deliver  additional,  high-quality  services  to  the  PDMCs.    Over  the  past  year  we  have 
conducted  extensive  consultations  with  the  full  range  of  ADB  members,  including  extensive 
direct consultations in the PDMCs by senior ADB officials.  In addition, we have benefited from 
direct feedback from the Executive Board, both through a full discussion in October 2002 of a 
working paper  on  possible  options,  as  well  as  in  a  subsequent  informal  seminar  on  a  revised 
approach.  All of this work has been extremely helpful in weighing alternatives, identifying and 
discussing issues of concern, and setting out the full range of views.   
 
6. 
The  purpose  of  this  paper  is  to  report  to  the  Board  on  the  results  of  this  analysis  and 
consultation,  and  to  present  a  revised  proposal,  summarized  below,  that  we  believe  is 
responsive to the various issues and concerns that have been raised.

Box 1: Proposed Approach 

 
•  A  Pacific  Subregional  Office  will  be  opened  in  Suva,  Fiji  Islands  in  2004;  this  office  would 
have the mandate to perform the full range of Resident Mission functions and would anchor 
our regional presence. 

 
•  A Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office will be opened in Sydney, Australia, also in 2004; 

this office would be a hybrid, performing both operational and coordination work. 

 
•  The  current  office  will  be  maintained  in  Port  Vila,  Vanuatu,  with  a  review  after  both  the 

Sydney and Suva offices are fully functional. 

 
 
7. 
Section  II  briefly  summarizes  relevant  elements  of  ADB’s  Resident  Mission  Policy. 
Section III identifies the key criteria against which alternatives were assessed, and summarizes 
key  findings  of  the  assessment.    Section  IV  presents  a  prospective  division  of  functions  and 
responsibilities between ADB headquarters and offices in the Pacific.  Section V briefly outlines 
the  proposed  organization  and  structure  of  the  proposed  offices.    Section  VI  highlights  the 
security  considerations.  Section  VII  outlines  the  incremental  costs  of  the  preferred  option. 
Section  VIII  discusses  the  expected  benefits  of  the  approach  outlined  above.  Section  IX 
presents  the  recommendations.  Appendix  1  outlines  the  detailed  analysis  of  six  optional 
locations.  Appendix  2  presents  the  expected  organization  and  structure  of  the  proposed  Suva 
office, with an estimate of costs. Appendix 3 presents the expected organization and structure of 
the  proposed  Sydney  office  and  summarizes  the  anticipated  costs  and  implementation 
schedule. 
 

II. 

ADB’S RESIDENT MISSION POLICY 

 
8. 
ADB’s  Resident  Mission  Policy  states  that  a  resident  mission  (RM)  should  be 
established “in each borrowing developing member country where it is practicable to establish 
it.”  However, the policy also explicitly recognizes the special circumstances of the PDMCs and 
the need for a pragmatic approach to dealing effectively with those circumstances.  In particular, 
the  policy  contemplates  that  individual  PDMCs  could  be  served  effectively  and  appropriately 
through  offices  not  physically  located  in  the  country  where  services  are  being  delivered.    The 
agreed upon policy thus builds in a degree of flexibility in light of the unique circumstances and 
challenges  of  the  Pacific  region.    The  policy recognizes that resident missions, while primarily 
operational, also have significant representation functions. 
 

III. 

RATIONALE AND JUSTIFICATION  

 

9. 
Against  the  background  of  both  the  flexibility  of  the  Resident  Mission  Policy,  and  the 
multiple  objectives  that  an  effective  field  presence  would  need  to  serve,  a  limited  set  of 
evaluation criteria were established.  The core objective was to arrive at a set of proposals that 
will  position  ADB  to  deliver  the  fullest  and  best  possible  service  to  the  PDMCs  within  a  very 
constrained resource envelope.  
 

  

3

Box 2: Evaluation Criteria 

 

 
•  Position  ADB  to  deliver  superior  KPS  to  its  PDMCs,  backed  by  financial 

resources.  

Increase the frequency of contact between ADB and PDMC officials, and 
the frequency of ADB participation in PDMC events. 

•  Optimize staff resources available for on-site operational work by reducing 

the current high proportion of mission time spent in transit. 

Increase ADB access to, and contact with, a greater range of key Pacific 
region development partners from both the public and private sectors.  

•  Ensure cost effectiveness.

Suva, Fiji Islands 

 
10. 
Of  six  possible  alternative  combinations  assessed  against  the  criteria  in  Box  2,  two 
emerged  as  the  dominant  options  for  cost-effective  offices:  Suva,  Fiji  Islands  and  Sydney, 
Australia (Appendix 1).3 Both offer attractive and, in many respects, complementary, features.  A 
careful assessment of the attributes and costs of each led to the conclusion that a presence in 
both locations, commencing in 2004, and combined with an ongoing anchor function in Manila 
and a full RM in PNG4, would offer maximum benefits. ADB’s current field presence in Vanuatu 
and in Timor-Leste would be reviewed once the Suva and Sydney offices are fully functional. 
 
A. 
 
Operational  Travel  Issues.  With  respect  to  operational  travel,  the  Fiji  Islands  offers 
11. 
advantages that exceed those of any other PDMC location.  The Fiji Islands is served by eight 
international airlines. On average, there are three flights per week from Nadi to other PDMCs, 
with  travel  time  of  less  than  1  day.5    Over  the  next  few  years,  the  Fiji  Islands  is  expected  to 
increase in importance as a travel hub for the Pacific, including through prospective upgrades of 
international air service direct to the Suva area. 
 
Direct Contact with PDMC Officials. The international airport at Nadi is a regional hub 
12. 
through  which  PDMC  officials  often  transit.  The  Fiji  Islands  hosts  numerous  conferences  and 
workshops.    Hence,  many  PDMC  working  level  officials  have  opportunities  to  travel  to  the  Fiji 
Islands,  and  about  20  senior  officials  could  be  expected  to  visit  an  ADB  office  in  Suva  each 
year.

14. 
facilities  have  limitations  and  are  relatively  costly,  the  Fiji  Islands  is  expected  to  build  up  its

B. 

Sydney, Australia 

15. 
Operational  Travel  Issues.  Sydney  has  major  advantages  in  terms  of  travel 
accessibility  and  interaction  with  ADB’s  stakeholders  and  development  partners  in  the  Pacific.   
Sydney is served by 44 international airlines providing 960 flights per week. On average there 
are 7.2 flights per week from Sydney to each PDMC, with travel time of less than 1 day. Sydney 
has long been the main “gateway” for ADB missions from Headquarters traveling to the PDMCs.   
 
16. 
Direct  Contact  with  PDMC  officials. On the basis of observed travel patterns, senior 
PDMC government officials and civil society delegation visits to or through Sydney would likely 
average at least 40 per year. This compares with eight government delegation visits per year on 
average  to  ADB  Headquarters  in  Manila.    Various  organizations  in  Sydney  regularly  host 
important development-related events involving senior PDMC officials.  At present, the majority 
of the ADB Institute’s seminars for senior Pacific officials are being held in Australia due to its 
accessibility and the availability of suitable facilities, including for larger conferences.  
 
17. 
Deepening Partnerships.  Sydney  has  the  largest  concentration  of  development  and 
academic institutions, multinational businesses and financial institutions, and civil society groups 
in  the  Southern  Pacific  region.    The  World  Bank  and  International  Finance  Corporation  have 
offices  there,  and  it  is  the  headquarters  of  the  South  Pacific  Project  Facility.  The  European 
Investment Bank is also considering opening its Pacific office in Sydney in 2003.  Sydney hosts 
numerous  Pacific  island  research  centers,  such  as  the  Research  Institute  for  Asia  and  the 
Pacific. Major international media groups are represented. Sydney is the regional headquarters 
for many major foreign and domestic banks, and hosts more than two thirds of the Asia-Pacific 
regional headquarters of multinational corporations. An ADB presence in Sydney, with a strong 
focus  on  liaison  and  coordination,  would  enable  ADB  to  more  effectively  project  its  own  and 
PDMC  views  to  the  wider  funding  community,  as  well  as  to  more  effectively  tap  into  the 
knowledge and experience of others.  Given PARD’s particular emphasis on delivery of KPS to 
its PDMCs, access to this broad community and pool of knowledge is a significant advantage.  
 
18. 
technology  and 
communications  facilities  are  excellent,  enabling  reliable  and  low-cost  contacts  with  key 
development partners in the region and globally; these facilities would also reduce the need for 
some travel, including by non-PARD Headquarters staff.

Overall Assessment 

C. 
 
19. 
The  combination  of  new  locations  seen  as  offering  the  highest  level  of  service, 
efficiency,  and  incremental  benefits  for  the  PDMCs  and  ADB  is  offices  in  both  Suva  and 
Sydney. A Sydney-based Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office (PLCO), to be opened in early 
2004,  will  provide  PDMCs  operational  services  on  a  selective  basis,  supplementing  continued 
Manila-based operations (Appendix 3). ADB would expect to open the main subregional office in 
Suva  later  in  2004  (Appendix  2),  with  our  Fiji  portfolio  having  expanded  significantly,  and  with 
better  travel  hub  and  communication  facilities  coming  on  stream.  Overall,  the  complementary 
nature of the two new offices in Suva and Sydney would make optimal use of their respective 
advantages  and  provide,  for  ADB  and  the  PDMCs,  the  strongest  possible  network  of  offices 
within the Pacific to enhance ADB’s responsiveness and the quality of its services (see Box 3).  
Once both offices are fully operational, our current offices in Vanuatu and Timor-Leste would be 
seriously reviewed, possibly retaining liaison staff only.7

In line with the objectives of the Resident Mission Policy, complementary offices in Suva 
and Sydney could be expected to perform all standard functions (government, civil society, and

B. 
 
21. 
Over  the  2-year  period  (2004–2005),  substantial  country  programming  and  project 
administration  responsibilities  would  be  shifted,  in  a  phased  manner,  to  the  new  offices.  The 
Pacific  Operations  Division  in  Headquarters  would  remain  the  focal  point  for  regional  strategy 
formulation and overall program coordination, substantial loan and TA project processing work, 
and country programming in the North Pacific DMCs (Marshall Islands and Federated State of 
Micronesia).  Continuing  significant  loan  processing  responsibility  at  Headquarters would help 
draw 
interaction  with  supporting  departments  (Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department, Office of the General Counsel, etc.) during the project design phase. 
However,  full  use  would  be  made  of  telecommunications  services  between Headquarters and 
the field, as well as PARD’s flexibility to deploy its sector experts to areas of greatest need. In 
view of the limited staff resources in PARD, it would be necessary to continue to operate in a 
flexible, matrix-style format, capitalizing on the specific expertise of staff regardless of location. 
To the extent possible, all staff would be given additional training to reinforce this objective and 
organizational structure. By 2005, the split between Manila-based and field-based professional 
staff  would  be  about  60:40,  although  this  would  be  kept  under  constant  review.  Importantly, 
most PARD staff outside ADB headquarters would be located in PDMCs. The  office alignment, 
liaison and coordination with key development partners, and emphasis on KPS delivery would 
also help ADB to make the most effective use of non-PARD staff expertise in the various ADB 
knowledge departments, in conducting research, post evaluation, training, and workshops in the 
Pacific region.  
 
The  RM  in  PNG  is  not  envisioned  as  having  a  subregional  function,  although  staff  are 
22. 
likely to be involved in regional activities, such as TA, training, and capacity building programs. 
The  office  in  Port  Vila  would  continue  to  emphasize  operations  on  Vanuatu,  where  a 
concentrated approach by ADB is needed to assist the Government to build on recent reforms 
supported  by  ADB.  However,  current  South  Pacific  Regional  Mission  staff  (including  support 
and  regional  staff)  have  built  up  considerable  knowledge  and  expertise  covering  other South 
Pacific countries, and they would be expected to contribute, as time and workloads permit, to 
the  functions  of  the  Sydney  and  Suva  offices,  particularly  in  the  transitional  period,  until  these 
offices become fully operational. PARD expects to make significant efforts to retain and recruit 
competent PDMC staff for all of ADB’s field locations. 
 

V. 

ORGANIZATION AND STRUCTURE 

 
23. 
The number of staff at the Pacific Subregional Office in Suva would reflect the workload 
anticipated in 2004 and beyond. The Suva subregional office would be established initially on a 
modest  scale,  with  three  professional  staff  (the  country  director  and  two  programs  or  projects 
officers/economists),  redeployed  from  ADB  headquarters.  Other  staff  would  consist  of  three 
regional  officers  (one  for  finance  and  administration  and  two  for  project  administration  and 
regional  economic  work)  and  six  nationally  recruited  administrative  staff  (See  Appendix  2).    In 
addition  to  an  expanding  portfolio  of  projects  in  the  Fiji  Islands,  the  subregional  office  would 
cover operations in Tonga, Samoa, and Tuvalu. 
 

  

7

The number of staff at PLCO would reflect its workload and hybrid nature. The Sydney 
24. 
office would be established on a modest scale, with four professional staff (the country director 
and  three  project  specialists/economists),  mainly  redeployed  from  ADB  headquarters.  Other 
staff  would  consist  of  three  regional  officers  (one  for  finance  and  administration  and  two  for 
project  administration  and  regional  economic  work)  and  five  support  staff.    To  the  extent 
possible,  staff  would  be  drawn  from  the  Pacific  region.    In  addition  to  its  essentially 
representation  functions,  the  office  would  be  operationally  responsible  for  all  of  the  southern 
PDMCs, and once the Pacific Subregional Office is fully functional, would remain responsible for 
Cook Islands, Nauru, Solomon Islands, and Kiribati.  PLCO would also provide back up support 
for  Timor-Leste  and  Vanuatu,  pending  future  decisions  on  the  scale  of  Pacific  offices  in  those 
locations. 
 

VI. 

SECURITY CONSIDERATIONS 

 
25. 
Fiji Islands has had a rather turbulent past, with coups in 1987 and 2000, in part related 
to  the  ethnic  mix.    Following  free  and  fair  elections,  the  Fiji  Labour  Party  has  challenged  the 
constitutionality of the current Government, and the Supreme Court is scheduled to address this 
issue in June 2003.  Nevertheless, legal processes are underway to resolve this issue, the coup 
leaders have been brought to justice, and the rule of law is firmly entrenched.  Fiji Islands has 
seen  an  upsurge  in  petty  crimes  over  the  past  few  years,  partly  as  a  result  of  the  poverty 
impacts triggered by the political unrest. The extent of criminal activities, however, is much less 
than in many DMCs.  In Sydney, there are no significant security concerns, and PLCO would be 
able  to  act  as  a  backstop  office  in  the  event  that  there  are  natural  disasters  or  political  crises 
that demand evacuation from other Pacific offices.  
 

VII. 

COSTS 

 
26. 
The  one-time  establishment  costs  of  the  Pacific  Subregional  Office  are  estimated  at 
about  $517,500  (Appendix  2),  which  reflects  the  capital  expenditure  requirements  of 
establishing  the  subregional  office.  The  first  full  year  of  operation  would  be  2005.  Associated 
cost reductions at headquarters and at South Pacific Regional Mission include (i) salaries and 
benefits of professional staff to be redeployed to the subregional office, and (ii) savings on the 
business travel costs of missions.  The impacts on ADB’s internal administrative expenses for 
2004  and  2005  are  estimated  at  $215,155  and  $292,631  respectively.  The  benefits  packages 
for staff assigned to the Pacific Subregional Office would follow standard ADB practice. 
 
The  one-time  establishment  costs  of  the  PLCO  are  estimated  at  about  $363,000 
27. 
(Appendix 3), which reflects the capital expenditure requirements of establishing PLCO. As for 
Suva,  cost  reductions  at  Headquarters  and  at  the  South  Pacific  Regional  Mission  include  (i) 
salaries  and  benefits  of  professional  staff  to  be  redeployed  to  PLCO,  and  (ii)  savings  on  the 
business  travel  costs  of  missions.  The  impacts  on  ADB’s  internal  administrative  expenses  for 
2004  and  2005  are  estimated  at  $627,610  and  $614,481  respectively.  The  benefits  packages 
for  staff  assigned  to  PLCO  would  follow  standard  ADB  practice;  much  lower  staff  allowance 
costs are expected given that the duty station is in a developed country.

RECOMMENDATION 

 
It  is  recommended  that  the  Board  approve  the  establishment  of  the  proposed  Pacific

Appendix 1

COMPARISON OF LOCATION OPTIONS FOR PACIFIC OFFICES 
 

Evaluation Process of Alternative Locations 

A. 
 
To  establish  a  resident  mission  (RM)  in  all  13  Pacific  developing  member  countries 
1. 
(PDMCs) would approximately double the operating costs of the Pacific Department (PARD) of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and (assuming no corresponding increase in professional 
staff)  leave  an  insufficient  number  of  core  staff  at  Headquarters  in  Manila  for  country 
programming  and  loan  processing.  Therefore,  some  amalgamation  of  staff  in  a  subregional 
office or offices will be necessary for the foreseeable future.  Since 1994, the number of staff in 
ADB's South Pacific Regional Mission (SPRM) located in Port Vila, Vanuatu has been gradually 
reduced due to Vanuatu's high cost and inconvenience as a travel hub.  As a subregional office, 
SPRM may be regarded as being suboptimal at present and is certainly considerably changed 
from its previous peak of 11 professional staff. Accordingly, a more suitable office arrangement 
is urgently required.  
 
The primary objective of establishing office(s) in the Pacific region is not to achieve the 
2. 
least-cost  option.  Rather,  the  objective is to meet the demands of ADB’s PDMC clients in the 
most  cost-effective  and  efficient  manner  possible.  The  PDMCs,  over  the  past  years,  have 
clearly expressed the demand side of the equation. They value most from ADB its policy advice 
and guidance on how best to develop their economies. In effect, they see ADB as augmenting 
their  own  human  resources,  filling  in  gaps  in  staff  competencies  and  providing  independent, 
reliable  policy  guidance,  technical  assistance  and  a  wide  variety  of  knowledge  products  and 
services  (KPS).  Compared  with  other  regional  departments  of  ADB,  PARD  provides  almost 
seven times the ADB average ratio of TA to loans, by amount (Table A1.1).

Of  course,  the  PDMCs  also  appreciate  that  these  TA  services  are  backed  up  by 
affordable  loan  financing.  However,  over  the  past  few  years  total  PDMC  borrowing  has  been 
only  about  $100  million  per  year.  In  2002,  this  dropped  to  less  than  $50  million.8 From the 
supply side, it would be  difficult  to  justify  running  a  department  that  costs  over  $8  million  per 
year solely on the basis of this small lending operation.

7. 
There are powerful arguments that apply to a Suva-based subregional office. In terms of 
contact  time,  the  principal  difference  between  Suva  and  Sydney  would  be  that  many  PDMC 
officials transit through Nadi, Fiji Islands but would rarely make a side trip to Suva.  Transit time 
savings  from  Nadi  would  be  similar  to  Sydney,  but  one  must  add  the  transit  from  Suva  to  the 
international  airport  at  Nadi,  which  often  makes  same-day travel to other PDMCs impossible. 
Hence the critical parameter of contact time would be less in Suva than in Sydney. 
 
The  other  significant  differences  between  scenario  1  and  scenario  2,  apart  from  one 
8. 
being  in  a  PDMC  and  the  other  in  a  developed  country,  are  (i)  travel  schedules  are  not  very 
convenient from Suva (most travel is through the international airport at Nadi, 3 hours away by 
road, and flights are often late at night or very early in the morning,11 necessitating an overnight 
stay  in  Nadi);  (ii)  several  PDMCs  are  not  directly  accessible  from  the  Fiji  Islands  and  require 
transit  through  Australia  or  New  Zealand;  (iii)  while  a  number  of  development  partners  are  in 
Suva,  there  is  no  cofinancing  institution  based  in  the  Fiji  Islands;  and  (iv)  communications  still 
need  to  be  improved,  partly  due  to  monopoly  control  by  FINTEL  and  Telecom  Fiji  (see  Table 
A1.3).

Compared  with  the  status  quo,  there  are  arguments  in  favor  of  closing  SPRM  and 
relocating the professional and regional staff to Sydney. SPRM currently costs $1.7 million per 
year (about 20% of PARD’s budget).12 Moreover, while a pleasant place to work, it is not a cost-
effective regional location. As most items are imported, largely from Australia, and there are few 
economies  of  scale,  Vanuatu  is  a  very  high-cost  location  for  international  business.  It  is  not 
conveniently  located  in  respect  of  most  PDMCs.  and  staff  must  transit  through  the  Fiji  Islands 
(Nadi)  or  Australia    (Sydney  or  Brisbane).  Communications  are  poor,  and  there  are  almost  no

Headquarters  from  Manila  due  to  its  inconvenience  as  a  travel  hub  and  increasing  security 
issues. Merely shifting the office from Port Vila to Suva would not provide an additional office in 
a PDMC, as requested by PDMC governments. 
 
22. 
The  main  advantages  of  this  option  over  Scenario  3  are  (i)  the  reduced  political 
consequences of closing a long-established office; (ii) the continued close contact of ADB staff 
with  the  Vanuatu  Government  at  a  time  of  real  fiscal  crisis;  (iii)  continued  close  supervision  of 
ongoing loan projects in Vanuatu, especially those that require travel to the outer islands; and 
(iv)  reduced  impact  on  loyal  and  experienced  local  ADB  support  staff  (see  Table  A1.9).  
Nevertheless, it is recognized that further review of the rationale for retaining Port Vila as an RM 
or liaison office would be needed once both offices in Suva and Sydney were fully functioning.

24.

this  is  not  yet  factored  into  the  calculation).  On  balance,  it  should  be possible to keep the 
incremental costs below 12%, for the maximum increase in contact time (18.2%).

25.

26. 
recent  review  of  the  RMs,18  and  would  not  satisfy  PDMC  preferences  for  an  increased  ADB

officials to offer policy advice and other KPS (see Table A1.11).

Summary 

 
D. 
 
31. 
If  cost  were  the  only  criterion,  closing  SPRM  and  returning  to  a  Headquarters-only 
operation  would  be  the  cheapest  option.  Given  the  undesirability  of  this  option,  opening one 
subregional  office  in  either  Suva  or  Sydney  and  closing  SPRM  would  be  the  next  cheapest 
option. However, without any significant increase in the current PARD budget, ADB can avail of 
the considerable complementary advantages of both locations —Suva and Sydney. In addition, 
this  combination  would  deliver  the  equivalent  of  almost  300  days  additional  contact  time  with 
PDMC officials, compared with 100 in Suva alone and almost 200 in Sydney alone. As PARD 
staff  currently  spend  about  60  days  per  year  on  average  in  contact  with  PDMC  officials,  this 
would  be  equivalent  to  increasing  the  contact  time  of  current  staff  by  about  20%  (see  Table 
A1.15). To reflect the monetary value of the increased or reduced contact time associated with 
each  option,  an  imputed  value  that  equates  an  additional  contact  day  by  ADB  staff  to  at  least 
the average cost of a staff consultant (at $500 per day) can be included in the analysis. At this 
relatively low imputed value, the actual costs of various options may be adjusted downwards by 
2-3%,  with  the  marginal  difference  increasing  as  the  number  of  contact  days  increases. 
Furthermore, this combination of complementary offices in Suva and Sydney would enable all of 
the PARD’s offices to improve communications with Headquarters (and staff on mission in other 
PDMCs)  through  a  hub  and  spoke  satellite  system,  using  Demand  Assigned  Multiple  Access. 
Accordingly, there would be corresponding reductions in the administrative costs of the Special 
Office in Timor-Leste and the RM in Papua New Guinea, plus back-up facilities in case of the 
need for evacuation.

32. 
Finally, for a small additional cost, a scaled-down RM or liaison office could be retained 
in  Vanuatu,  without  exceeding  ADB-wide  budget  constraints.  Such  a  decision  (even  if  only 
temporary) would (i) be politically sound, (ii) ensure continuity of project administration expertise 
until the subregional offices are fully operational, and (iii) initially assist the Vanuatu Government 
as it attempts to cope with a severe fiscal crisis. In addition, of all the options considered, this 
scenario  would  maximize  the  amount  of  contact  days  with  senior  government  officials 
(estimated at about 18.2%). 
 
33. 
In summary, to best meet the objectives set out in para. 2, a combination of Suva and 
Sydney  offices,  plus  downscaling  SPRM  to  a  Vanuatu  RM  or  liaison  office  (at  least  until  both 
Suva  and  Sydney  are  fully  operational  in  2005)  is  supported  by  the  above  analysis.  A  serious 
review  of  the  continued  viability  of  the  scaled-down  Vanuatu  office  would  be  carried  out  once 
both the Suva and Sydney offices are fully functional.

to  computer  systems  at  Headquarters,  and  good

4.

facilitate the matrix staffing arrangement, which would permit sector specialists from one office 
to work in countries under the nominal control of another office.

ORGANIZATION, STRUCTURE, AND COST OF PACIFIC LIAISON AND 
COORDINATION OFFICE – SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA 

 

1. 
In accordance with its normal practice, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) would enter 
into a host country agreement (HCA) with the Government of Australia to ensure the recognition 
of  ADB  status  and  that  the  relevant  privileges  and  immunities  are  provided  for  ADB,  its 
operations,  and  staff.  The  HCA  negotiations  would  be  finalized  prior  to  opening  the  Pacific 
Liaison and Coordination Office (PLCO). 
 
2. 
The  number  of  staff  at  PLCO  would  reflect  its  workload.  The  Sydney  office  would  be 
established  on  a  modest  scale,  with  four  professional  staff  (the  country  director  and  three 
project  specialists/economists),  mainly  redeployed  from  ADB  headquarters.  Other  staff  would 
consist  of  three  regional  officers  (one  for  finance  and  administration  and  two  for  project 
administration and regional economic work) and five support staff.  To the extent possible, staff 
would be drawn from the Pacific region.  
 
To ensure efficient operations and rapid response capability, PLCO must have the same 
3. 
access  to  data  and  information  as  Headquarters  staff.  Investments  in  information  technology, 
access  to  computer  systems  at  Headquarters,  and  good  communications  systems,  including 
videoconferencing  facilities,  would  be  necessary  to  achieve  the  benefits  expected  from  the 
office.  Advanced  information  technology  and  telecommunications  facilities  are  necessary tools 
to make PLCO a real extension of ADB and integrate the office into Headquarters functions. 
 
4. 
Despite  having  significant  representative  office  functions,  PLCO  would  be  under  the 
overall  supervision  of  the  director  general,  PARD.  To  take  full  advantage of ADB’s presence 
within the Pacific region and proximity to Pacific developing member countries, PLCO must be 
able  to  respond  quickly  and  decisively.  The  benefits  of  establishing  a  Sydney  office  must  be 
matched  by  adequate  prudential  oversight  to  maintain  the  transparency  and  integrity  of  ADB 
operations.  Appropriate  fiduciary  controls  and  the  application  of  ADB’s  current  procedures  for 
procurement  of  goods  and  services  would  be  ensured.  Disbursement  functions  would  only  be 
delegated  to  PLCO  subject  to  detailed  guidelines  issued  by  ADB’s  Controller.  Internal  control 
mechanisms would be put in place to prevent any misuse or abuse of delegated authority, along 
with appropriate audit functions.  
 
5. 
The estimated costs of the proposed Sydney-based PLCO and its associated budgetary 
impact for 2004 and 2005 are detailed below. The one-time establishment costs of the office are 
estimated at about $363,000 (Table A3.1), which reflects the capital expenditure requirements 
of establishing PLCO. Table A3.2 shows the costs for operating an office in Sydney, and Table 
A3.3 shows incremental internal administrative expenses.  Cost reduction at Headquarters and 
at the South Pacific Regional Mission includes (i) salaries and benefits of professional staff to be 
redeployed to PLCO, and (ii) savings on the business travel costs of missions. The impacts on 
ADB’s  internal  administrative  expenses  for  2004  and  2005  are  estimated  at  $627,610  and 
$614,481, respectively. The benefits packages for staff assigned to PLCO would follow standard 
ADB practice; much lower staff allowance costs are expected, given that the duty station is in a 
developed country.
